Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from an NLRB dataset covering 1999-2011 downloaded at https://catalog.data.gov/dataset/nlrb-cats-final-c-case-data-bulk-19990101-20110930-in-xml

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Company: GMRI, Inc. d/b/a The Capital Grille
Description: back pay award in unfair labor practices case
Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/16/2017.

Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Private Litigation Case Title: Chhab v. Darden Restaurants, Inc. et al

Notes: In a March 2007 SEC filing Darden disclosed that it had agreed to pay a total of $11 million to settle five state wage & hour cases in California but did not provide details of the cases.

Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Sacramento
Notes: Two California state wage & hour cases filed in Orange County Superior Court were consolidated with a third case filed in Sacramento County and jointly settled in 2005 for a total of $9.5 million. See also: http://wagelaw.typepad.com/wage_law/2005/06/red_lobsteroliv.html
Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: The California Attorney General announced the settlement of an environmental lawsuit against major restaurant chains under which hundreds of restaurants statewide will be required to post warnings for patrons about mercury in fish. The defendants also agreed to pay civil penalties and fund a consumer education program.
